Kenny: the link to listen to the audio for Philippians overview doesn't work because it includes the work Review in it. If I have time, I'll try and fix it. Otherwise most of the other links should work. Also, in Philippians, I see such a view from Paul about treating Christianity with such a realistic view of how it's a life and death commitment i.e. being poured out as a drink offering, Timothy risking his life to complete service that the Philippians we're lacking, Paul talking about knowing how to live in any/every circumstance, etc. Maybe it's because Paul is at the end of his life and in jail, but I found it encouraging to read through this book with the perspective of following Christ as a life and death kind of deal, not just the simple American Christian life that I'm so comfortably living.
Devon RE Kenny: Good insight. I really enjoy Philippians; always have. I love how much Paul focuses on being joyful and living out our lives with a joyous hope in God. I think my takeaway is to be ever more joyful in my own life. I am so FREAKING blessed and have such a wonderful anchor of hope that I can't stand the thought of not being joyful!

Corey: the phrases "without excuse" and "God gave them up to..." stand out to me. God's simple action with sinner is to allow us to live how we please -  and since we are living how we please, we have no excuse, no possible way to escape blame. We are truly responsible for everything - even our thoughts.

Josh: I found myself taking comfort in the terminology "God gave them up." Comfort that there was no other possible reaction from a holy God.

Kenny: not to mention that the whole reading starts off with "for the wrath of God is revealed..."

Kenny: hmm... After using our new tool for a few days, I realized that we won't see people's comments that post later in the day than us unless we click back to the previous day. Thoughts? An icon on the button depicting unread messages would be cool. Another option would be a running comment log (like prayers) or we can just make it a habit of checking the previous day every day.
Leal: I have no idea how hard the programming would be for such a feature, but an unread message icon would be pretty dope if it isn't crazy hard to do.
Devon: Unread message counter would be cool and not too hard but part of the reason I wanted us to have a "wrap up" day for each book is so that we could review all previous comments and pray over them. If it's very much work I wouldn't worry to much, Kenny, about making the counter. But it's your call.
Devon: "Everyone who does good"; I don't believe a non-believer can do good. They literally are incapable of doing good because they do not do so out of the Holy Spirit. in Romans 8:8 we see this backed up. From this perspective, this whole chapter and passage makes so much more sense to me.
Devon: In Genesis we see that all men received a knowledge of good and evil the moment that Adam and Eve ate from that tree, but it doesn't mean that all men knew the specifics of the Mosaic law that God handed to the Israelites. I think that's another good reason we can give to people who ask why we don't follow the OT law. And that reason is that that law was not written on our hearts as the moral law was.
Kenny RE Devon 1: when Paul says "glory, honor and peace to everyone who does good" does he mean that they will be rewarded extra to what we already receive as believers?

Josh: A verse that really stood out to me in my prayer time was v21. I started praying and asking God some of the things I might be verbally or non-verbally teaching the people in my life. It was a good prayer exercise! I am also thankful that of all the things that came to mind, I am not under the law but under Christ. It is empowering to rest in that and the work of the Holy Spirit over my hippocritical teaching.

Kenny RE Josh: Sounds like a really convicting prayer! I agree that it's nice that it's not up to our perfect teaching / behavior to teach others about the gospel and that God will work in us even through our hypocritical ways.

Kenny: if you see this, that means that the unread comment feature is working!!

Kenny: I realized that verse 14 in the ESV translation uses a word that I have no idea what it meant until I looked at other translations. The word is "adherent". I liked the NLT translation "If God's promise is only for those who obey the law, then faith is not necessary and the promise is pointless." I'm other words. I was encouraged to see how the gospel and living by faith is a theme from Abraham until 2018. And Romans 4 is flowing with that theme.
P.s. this app will have security and unread message enhancements coming soon...

Josh: A little note on the usage of the word "justified." I visited my brother in Chicago a few years ago while he was attending the Moody Bible Institute, and I sat in on his Systematic Theology class one evening. It was awesome, and right up my alley. The concept of Justification came up at one point in the three-hour lecture, and I learned a pretty helpful and eccentric word. The word is "righteous-ified," as opposed to "justified." Anytime you come across "justified" in Romans, it has always been easier for me to replace the word with "righteous-ified" instead, to represent that this concept of justification is the process of God making us righteous. What an awesome concept, guys.

Kenny re Josh: that is awesome! Thanks for sharing that nugget of wisdom.

Devon RE Josh: I really like that. One thing I learned a while ago (not sure where) is that the word justified is kind of like saying "Just if I'd" never sinned. Which is to be righteous before God.

Devon: What's the difference between a righteous man and a good man? I suppose it's simply in the eyes of the people. A righteous man would be in good standing before God and a good man would be in good standing before men (that's a bit of a paraphrase but you get the idea). We see this word "good" show up a lot in the New Testament and it is applied to a number of things but always makes me wonder what it means because Christ pretty much says "nothing is really good except God".
Kenny RE Devon: This is what the ESV commentary says about the righteous vs good man: " On rare occasions, even a human being will die for a righteous (morally upright) person or for a good person (one who has done much good)." Is the "good" used in this passage the same root for the good used in the NT?

Kenny: My pastor shared an illustration of "sinning more that grace may abound" that I liked. Imagine a father sending his daughter off to college and the father gives the daughter a credit card with a $10,000 credit limit, but tells her to only spend $2,000 per semester. How silly it would be for the daughter to max out the $10,000 limit and for her to tell her friends "look at how loving and forgiving my Dad is going to be!" Now, is the dad going to forgive her? Of course. Does that mean that she was in the right to spend $10,000? No way.

Devon: Boy I tell ya what the harder I think about this whole "The commandment made sin more effective" business, the more my head hurts. What does it mean that apart from law, sin in dead? Why would God add a commandment if he knew the future and the fact that by doing so would only cause use greater sin? Certainly he does it so that he might show is own grace but does it not go against his own character to lead us into more sin by presenting us with the need to break the law? Or is this just the same as him testing us like we see in James? ...This hurts my brain. Addendum: I suppose it's really not that different than God placing the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and Evil in the Garden of Eden and saying, "don't eat from this". God could just have soon not made the freaking tree and then all would be well but then he would have no outlet to convey is infinite grace and mercy and justice and wrath and so many other attributes of himself.
Devon: One step further: Do you think that this idea that we see of sin not being taken into account when the law is not known (John 9:41, John 15:22, Romans 5:13) plays into the age old question of "What about the poor soul on the desert island who never even knew about the law?"?

Kenny RE Devon: Those are all great questions. I think that the "apart from the law, sin lies dead" reference is talking about before sin was in the world, there was no law and hence sin was dead. As for your question about why would God do X if he knew it was gonna happen came up in bible study tonight. Another example is when God "regretted" creating man (Genesis 6:67). Our conclusion was that God didn't regret it in the sense that he wish that he made a mistake, but in the sense that he was sad that he had to flood the earth.
Kenny RE Devon pt2: The verses you reference are interesting. At first glance it seems that if someone never knew right vs. wrong let alone Jesus and the bible that they would be completely free of the law/sin/judgement/etc. Doesn't C.S. Lewis argue in Mere Christianity that God has to exist because we have a moral code engrained into our hearts? Also, we see in Romans 1:20 that men are without excuse, Romans 3:23 that all are without sin. Also, Drew Frazer has the infamous IBC story of how he believes that the man on the island doesn't exist. You know and understand who God is and you need to make that decision to follow him or not.

Kenny: verse 3 "By sending his own son in the likeness of sinful flesh". What do you guys think it means that Jesus was in the likeness of sinful flesh? Was Jesus' Is flesh inherently sinful? Which is why Jesus was sent in the likeness of it?
Devon RE Kenny: I didn't read the whole article but I like what this has to say about it. This would also be my answer but I think this answers it more tactfully. https://carm.org/what-does-it-mean-that-jesus-was-made-in-the-likeness-of-sinful-flesh

Kenny: oops. I accudently studied the whole chapter. Did you guys see that article about that lady that got backlash after saying that Stephen Hawking was "free from his physical constraints" after he died? I thought that it was interesting with the lens of v20. Who are we to question God and how he made us? God knew exactly what he was doing.

Josh: Awwww. I missed the predestination chapter. Any thoughts about this? God speak to anyone about anything involving predestination?
Devon: I'm very distracted as I sit hear reading and I can't seem to think for more than 4 seconds but what do you guys think verses 5 through 7 mean?
Devon: I'm very distracted as I sit hear reading and I can't seem to think for more than 4 seconds but what do you guys think verses 5 through 7 mean?

Kenny: I didn't copy the conversation history over. Hopefully that's okay with everyone

Kenny: Verse 8 is a really great verse to meditate on. 

Kenny RE Kenny: Nice verse! I'm testing to see how these comments will work.

Kenny: testing on mobile

Corey: Fully agree on verse 8. That easily set my tone for the day - and helped me to turn off the over analytical side of my brain with Jen for the day
Kenny: What do you guys think it means that we're more than conquerors?

Kenny: you can almost feel the sense of urgency with Paul in verse 11. He probably has the idea that Christ was gonna come back in the next few years and that time was painfully limited to preach the gospel. I pray that we can also have that similar urgency.

Kenny: What do you guys think it means to "outdo one another in showing honor"? I've always thought of it as a competitive-be-better-than-everyone-else-at-showing-honor. My guess is that Paul is getting at not a competitive show honor, but a genuine love and delight in showing love for other brothers.
Leal: Kenny, I think that your assessment is spot on. In NIV verse 10 says, "Be devoted to one another in love. Honor one another above yourselves."

Kenny: Also, you guys will notice some upgrades to the app. We all now have assigned colors. Let me know if you guys want to change them. If you edit the reading content, the color will be assigned to you. Also I added in a race condition check. If two of us try and submit something at the same time, it will warn the 2nd submission saying that the page is out of date and they need to refresh.
Leal: This tool is the bomb! Thanks again for putting it together and for continuing to make it even better! My only recommendation is that you switch my color with Corey's ;)
Kenny RE Leal: I'll have up get to it later. How about I change Corey to red?
Kenny: what did you guys think of verse 17? Do you think the kingdom of God is referring to heaven? Or do you think it's referring to right now in this moment?

Devon: What do you think it means to "glory" in Christ Jesus? Is that to be glorified (and if so what does that look like) or is it to be awestruck by glory of Christ, or is it something else.

Devon: What do you think verse 27 looks like today? Are we not still sharing in their spiritual blessings?

Kenny: I wish we could camp out in Romans for an entire year. It's such a rich text.
Devon RE Kenny: I know, I still didn't dig in nearly as much as I would have liked to.

Kenny: Why is everything meaningless according to the author/probably Solomon? It almost seems like a secular view. I believe that this scripture is God breathed, and there must be deep takeaways from this text, but I have a hard time seeing them. Is the takeaway from "everything is meaningless/vanity" that we shouldn't care about anything on this earth? What do you guys think?
Devon RE Kenny: One of my favorite verses in the bible is Eccl 12:13. In this verse Solomon says "Now all has been heard; here is the conclusion of the matter: fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man." I think that in my mind it answers that question. I think Solomon is saying that all the worry, all the anxiety, all the hurt, everything about this world that weighs so much on us is really not worth the worry. Only one thing really matters and that is following God.

Kenny: what did you guys think about verse 11? It's interesting that he says he put eternity in the man's heart but we cannot find out what God has done throughout eternity essentially. So what exactly does it mean that he has put eternity into man's heart?
Devon RE Kenny: At first thought it could certainly be the fact that all men throughout the ages have sought eternal life. Everyone fears death and the myth of living forever has been a prominent thought process throughout the time of human kind on earth. Essentially, we want to live forever, but we cannot. We want to live in paradise but all things wither and fade away.
Kenny: I really enjoyed verse 9 "Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the appetite". In other words, appreciate what you have instead of wishing for more.

Corey: What do you guys think of the authorship? I know tradition says Solomon, and as the wisest man alive, Solomon would make even more sense - but there's quite the speculation among scholars Christian and otherwise as to who truly wrote the book. I'm inclined to lean towards Solomon, but I'm very unsure. In one sense though, the uncertain authorship may indeed be an even higher statement to the wisdom in the book. The wisdom is not that of a certain person - not to be attributed to a time frame, or particular set of experiences. It is simply a piece of wisdom on living life as a human being. Thoughts?

Kenny RE Corey: I feel like the authorship of almost every book is challenged. Here are some snippets from the ESV study bible.
Arguments for Solomon
v1: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
v16: I said in my heart, I have acquired great wisdom, surpassing all who were over Jerusalem before me, and my heart has had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.
Rebuttal
(1) The phrase son of David could refer to any legitimate David descendant, as it does in Matthew 1:20 with reference to Joseph and frequently throughout the NT with reference to Jesus Christ. 
(2) The distinctive nature of the Hebrew language used in the book is widely believed to be indicative of a date much later than the 10th century B.C.
(3) The Preachers remarks imply a historical setting that seems in tension with the Solomonic era, such as the fact that many have preceded him as king in Jerusalem
I suppose that in the end, it doesn't matter and that it's the bible / God's word to be trusted at the end of the day.

Devon RE Corey: I think I'm of the opinion quite firmly that Solomon wrote it. Like Kenny said, just about every book in the bible is challenged in terms of the author but there are a number of statements and frankly the entire plot of the book at are far to similar to Solomon for any other author to make sense.

Kenny: These are some of the verses that Drew read to Aubrey and I as we begin to think through our vows that we will give at our wedding. Aside from marriage, I think it's a good reminder to be careful with our tongues. "4 When you vow a vow to God, do not delay paying it, for he has no pleasure in fools. Pay what you vow. 5 It is better that you should not vow than that you should vow and not pay."
Devon RE Kenny: Yea that's a really good point. I wish that was taken more seriously with the modern world.

Devon: I like verse 1. It's kinda in line with what Kenny said a couple days ago but basically it's better to be respected than to be rich.

Devon: What do you guys think of verse 3 when it says that sadness is good for the heart? 

Devon: 21 and 22 are so wise. I love those.

Devon: Sorry for so many questions but what on earth is going on in 28? What are your thoughts on that?

Kenny Re Devon: I was wondering about that too. The second half of the verse says sorrow makes the heart glad. I wonder if it's a happiness versus joy kind of argument he is explaining. Like he's saying that sorrow is better than happiness.

I agree 21-22 are really convicting.

You can never ask too many questions! And I have no idea what it means.

Kenny: any ideas on what verse 10 means?

Devon RE Kenny: I would guess he is saying that we don't have much time here on earth so we need to be careful to make the most of the time we do have.

Devon: What do you guys think verse 11 is talking about?

Devon: It is interesting that we still see the idea of noble birth in the Bible also. In America today we love the idea of an underdog or a homeless person hitting it big and rising though the ranks but that is not the case even with the wisest man who ever lived.

Kenny RE Devon: the verses surrounding verse 11 seem to be giving examples of how wisdom > foolishness. I'm not exactly sure how that relates to the charmer and snake though.

Devon: I really don't understand most of this chapter. Weird sayings...

Kenny RE Devon: yeah this has been an interesting book to dig into.
Kenny: I wonder why the author is so passionate about pursuing God in your youth. It almost sounds like he is speaking from experience. Also, the last verse was convicting in a good way.
Kenny: I still feel thoroughly confused about Ecclesiastes. There's a lot of wisdom to it, but the whole everything is Vanity still kind of puzzles me.

Devon: Gentlemen we need more reading. In 5 more days we will be back to Genesis. Y'all gotta track down some stuff for us!

Devon: It is fairly likely that Nero was emperor of Rome when James wrote this book and it's also certainly possible that this writing took place after the great fire for which Nero blamed the Christians which lead to brutal Christian persecution. With that in mind, James, as the believed leader (or at least one of them) of the council in Jerusalem would have a lot to think about when writing this. I'm not sure how that affects me when I read it but it's interesting to keep in mind that what he is saying has that in its background.

Kenny RE Devon: I'll add some chapters! Also, interesting perspective.

Josh: RE Devon: Thought I should mention that it now widely accepted that James wrote his book sometime between 40 and 45, which is 10ish years before Nero's start to his reign.

Devon RE Josh: Interesting. That's a good catch. You're right that's well before Nero was even in power no less the fire that lead to Christian persecution.

Leal - James is probably the most convicting book in the Bible for me. This was appropriately timed and was very beneficial.

Kenny RE Leal: Yeah James is an excellent book. I hope that the fruit of this book continues to penetrate our lives for weeks and weeks to come.

Devon: Verse 9 sounds a lot like Ecclesiastes.

Devon: What does it mean to judge the law? I know we use the law as we want to judge others but to judge the law itself it a strange concept.

Devon: How do you think verse 17 really fits into this section? It sounds kinda out of place.

Kenny RE Devon: Verse 9 is kind of a weird verse. Judging the law to me means that we are saying that we can write better laws than this. Verse 17 I read "in the context of life being short..." we should captivate on ministry opportunities because missed ministry opportunities can be sinful.

Corey: RE Devon and Kenny: To me, Verse 9 flows in the context.The previous few verses all speak about us as adulterous people - sinners and double-minded. People who have not come near to God, people who have not resisted the Devil, and have made friendship with the world. Thus, displaying a level of happiness and joy in friendship with the world. To me, it points to a self-reflection of our own sins, a recognition of how we have some up short before God, and points to the need to be humbled. I agree spot on with Kenny's assessment of judging the law.  My reading of verse 17 also fits closely with Kenny's - I see it as a warning against planning to do the right thing later, thus acquitting ourselves of the need to respond now. If we know the right thing to do, and we do not do it - for whatever reason, even saying "I'll do that tomorrow," is evil. Following God is urgent, and God judges our heart.

Devon: why does James say "above all" in verse 12? Why is THAT of all that he has said the most important thing?

Devon: I'm always puzzled by verses like 15 where it is issued as a guarantee. How often have men and women of great faith prayed for healing that did not come about?

Kenny re Devon: I am not sure why it says above all. I have a friend from church who I grew up with. When he was really little his mom had cancer and his dad told him to pray and if he prayed hard enough she'll be healed. She ended up dying and it wrecked him for awhile. He's now in seminary.

Corey RE Devon: In regards to verse 15, I think the definitions of the words "powerful and effective" must be carefully held. Particularly "Effective." Effective to what end? Oh wait. Placing it in context, effective is with the context of making the sick person well. My argument just collapsed on itself. Yeah, I got nothing til I think about it more. Count me baffled. 

Corey RE Devon: I also sit in confusion at the line "Above all." One of the common themes in James mentioned every chapter is some sort of variation on controlling the tongue - I wonder if this is, to James, the culmination of taming the tongue? 1:26 encourages a tight reign on the tongue, 2:12 encourages us to "Speak and act..." noting the order of speaking first, chapter 3 spends a long time talking of the tongue, chapter 4 speaks much to not slandering eachother with speech, then goes on to tell us not to boast - both our tongue's actions. Frame 5:12 with this - and I wonder if this was James's culmination of his letter. He speaks so much of our speech, and how critical our words are. Taking that into context....maybe swearing is being taken as the ultimate way of using our tongues to assert a level of control. When we swear, we imply that we ourselves have control over what happens in our lives. If our words are inevitably the overflow of what we believe in our heart - and I think James is building that point through his entire book - the summit of what he haves to say is captured in the heart condition behind swearing. A condition where we imply complete control over our lives, idolizing ourselves, and putting so much value in our own ability to fulfill our Word. So....I guess that's why I think James used the words "Above all." But that may be completely off target, and I confess to a mild amount of speculation in this conclusion.

Kenny: what do you guys think it means that God has spoken to us by his son? Does that mean that Jesus' words in the NT are how God speaks to us? Or does it mean that Jesus has the ability to speak to us?

Also, as a tip I learned from the last time that I studied Hebrews in depth, if you're ever confused about something, the answer is probably both.

Devon: Verse 8: Just as we learn and grow through trials and tribulations, so also the Son of God himself also learned and developed by the difficult things he faced.

Devon: What do you suppose it means in verse 9 when it says "once made perfect"? Wasn't Jesus always perfect? And at what point, then, was he made priest? Perhaps this is talking about his baptism?

Kenny RE Devon: I read "being made perfect" as "he grew towards completing a perfect human life". Jesus was always the priest "You are a priest forever"? I'm not sure

Devon RE Kenny: Oh I like that interpretation!

Kenny: I feel like it'd be wrong to glance over verses 4, 5 and 6. When it says "those who have once been enlightened, who have tasted the heavenly gift the heavenly gift, and shave shared in the Holy Spirit, and have tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the age to come", I don't believe that it is referring to born again christians. We see many examples of God's saved by grace through faith scriptures all over the bible. My favorite one is John 10:28 "I give them eternal life, and they will never perish, and no one will snatch them out of my hand." I think some would argue that you yourself could snatch yourself out of God's hand, but I suppose that you would have never had salvation to begin with.

Devon RE Kenny: I kinda did want to skip this one just cause it's so in contrast with the rest of scripture that we could argue the point until the cows come home. Ultimately I don't see this verse doing any benefit to my faith or any other but I suppose I can offer my two cents. I think that scripture is very clear that we cannot lose our salvation by any deed or sin that we commit, and I don't see this verse going against that in any way. I have always believed that just as I had the free will to follow God (however free will and election play together for it is clear they both exist through some cosmic mystery that only God can fathom) so also I have the choice to leave him. Now you could ask why, after tasting the goodness of God and sharing in the Holy Spirit (as the verse says) I would ever want to leave and I have no clue; as far as I'm concerned you never would want to leave. But that does not mean that I CAN'T leave. This verse is so painstakingly clearly that it is talking about someone who was 100% saved that I can't ignore that. The author describes in every way, and then some, the characteristics of a true Christian (sharing in the Holy Spirit --> Only comes through faith, tasted the heavenly gift --> either salvation or the full grace of God, enlightened --> clearly conscious of their position and what is going on, tasted the goodness of the word of God and the powers of the coming age --> fully in touch with God and his all consuming power) and thus I MUST come to the conclusion that this verse is talking about someone walking away. It even says "if they fall away" suggesting their choice not God pushing them away. Whew! That was a lot!

Kenny: what did you guys think of this verse? V26 - "For if we go on sinning deliberately after receiving the knowledge of the truth, there no longer remains a sacrifice for sins, but a fearful expectation of judgment, and a fury of fire that will consume the adversaries." If it means exactly what it sounds like, then sinning deliberately sounds really bad.

Devon RE Kenny: I suppose in context of the rest of scripture especially in 1 John that this is someone who chooses a lifestyle of sin that is ongoing; an unfortunate example would be a homosexual choosing to stay with their partner after "being saved".

Kenny: it's kind of funny that the Nav20s Bible study is about Elijah and the story of how God destroys Elijah's offering with fire to prove that Baal is not worth worshipping. The last verse in this chapter of Hebrews is a good reminder that God will burn up anything that is not holy.

Devon: So what's your guys' takeaway from Hebrews?

Kenny: I have a few takeaways
- Jesus was the perfect sacrifice, yet he was fully human and God and able to relate to us (2:17-18, 4:15, 9:12, 12:3, etc. I'm sure there are a ton more)
- We as Christian's are called to encourage others (3:13-14, 10:24-35)
- God used imperfect people to represent what it means to have faith in God (ch 11)
- We are to have a high respect for our leaders (13:7, 17 and 24).
- Hebrews has a lot of good stuff in it.

Kenny: fellas, any thoughts on what book to go through next? I'd enjoy going through one of the gospels.

Kenny: verse 5 says "Having the appearance of godliness, but denying its power. Avoid such people." Would you guys consider Mormons to fall under this? What about other religions?

Devon RE Kenny: That's a good question. I think that makes sense to me personally or in general anyone who claims to "believe in God" but does not hold Christ as King. But then how do we reconcile that with avoiding them?

Kenny: have you guys heard of the 5 crowns that believers can "get"? I think I remember Josh had some good insights on the crowns when we did a study on 2 Timothy way back when I first got involved with Nav20s. Here is a link for more detail https://www.gotquestions.org/heavenly-crowns.html

Kenny: My senior year I was in the seniors study led by Drew Frazer. There were about 9 guys in the study and we were studying Psalm 1. We eventually got into a heated discussion on what it meant that the tree in verse 3 was bearing fruit. We talked about how it could be the fruit of the spirit, how it could be relating to abiding in the vine as mentioned in John 15 and maybe a few other things in there. At one point Drew brought us back into reality when he reminded us that the psalms are poems and shouldn't be taken too literally. A tree planted in water yielding fruit is just doing what a tree is doing when it's well nourished. We likewise are to be well nourished by delighting in the law of the Lord and we will be able to prosper in everything that we do.
Kenny: verse 14 - Wait for the LORD; be strong, and let your heart take courage; wait for the LORD! What do you guys think it means to wait for the Lord?

Kenny: This is my favorite Psalm! Specifically, Verse 1: "The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky above proclaims his handiwork." Verse 10: "[God's laws] More to be desired are they than gold, even much fine gold." And Verse 14: "Let the words of my mouth and the meditation of my heart be acceptable in your sight, O LORD, my rock and my redeemer."
Kenny: There is a lot of sand out there. It's overwhelming that God has that many thoughts toward us.

Kenny:  Your love, oh Lord
Reaches to the heavens
Your faithfulness stretches to the sky
Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains
Your justice flows like the ocean's tide

Devon: I like these verses that keep coming up and saying to be patient and wait for the Lord. I really just want to see results now but that's not God's plan nor may I ever see my desires come to fruition in my day but I trust that the Lord is working.

Corey: Amen to what Devon said. Another thing that hit me today. Verse 4 says to delight in the lord, and he will give us the desires of our heart. So often, I hear verses like this read to "justify" using God as a genie go get what we want. Or I hear it fired back from non-Christians as to why our God is so weak and doesn't give us what we want. Butthere's a clue in the text. If we delight in the Lord....our desires change. True delight in the Lord results in a reordering of the desires - to where verse 3, dwelling in the Lords pasture, becomes our desires. Just because God is choosing not to give me an answer on marrying Jen doesn't mean that God isn't giving me the desires of my heart - rather, it points to disordered desires. This may sound obvious written out....but it feels like a big deal.

Kenny: verse 4 is so amazing. "He determines the number of the stars; he gives to all of them their names." Devon could probably elaborate better on how many stars there are, but I know that the answer is ALOT.
Devon RE Kenny: People figure with a rough guess there are probably around 1 Septillion stars in the observable universe (1,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000). Kenny: I'm always intrigued by the devil quoting scripture in the temptation of Jesus. Devon RE Kenny: Verse 21 is actually really cool to me. Nathan shared something in bible study the other day that I hadn't really given a lot of thought to: Basically, Jesus opens up the OT and begins reading from Isaiah 61:1,2. Now, Isaiah 61:1-2 is a prophecy for the future, and indeed Jesus is the fulfillment of that prophecy or at least MOST of it at that present time. You notice that Jesus only reads up through the beginning of 2 where it says "to proclaim the year of the Lord's favor" and then he stops right there! Clearly not finishing the "verse". That's because the second half of 2 hadn't happened it! That is still to come in the future. It's a really cool look at how God does prophecy; Just because we see one single verse talking about something doesn't mean that the things of that verse are going to happen at the same time, or even within 2000 years of each other. That means that the second half of verse 2 may not have even happened yet while the first was fulfilled over 2000 years ago! Cool stuff.

Devon: Alright Gentlemen. I need some thoughts. God is holy. He is infinitely perfect. Because of this, the only proper response to sin for an infinitely holy God is an infinite punishment, i.e. hell. This makes sense to me. To downplay our sin is to downplay God's holiness. This is typically the response I would give to someone if they asked about hell and how that is fair. Chase had a great illustration that I thought fit this: If you were to lie to me, the consequence would be that maybe I don't trust you anymore or I tell someone else you aren't trustworthy (not really all that bad of a consequence). If you lie to a federal judge, you go to jail; no "ifs", "ands", or "buts", you're going to jail. So then if the difference in consequence for the same transgression is that significant just between two people (both of those people broken, imperfect, beings). How much more for an infinitely holy God?!?! Again, hell makes a LOT of sense to me for it is the only proper/possible response for our God in response to our sin. If this is true, and our sin requires an infinite punishment to account for it (or else hell isn't fair if only some people go), then how is it that Christ can pay the price for our sins and not be in hell for eternity to pay for it?

Kenny RE Devon: That's a cool illustration. I've wondered that too about Jesus dying but not having to suffer the consequences for eternity. My short answer is: when Christ is that Jesus Death on the cross must be more painful to God than we could ever imagine.

Kenny: Hey guys, since no one jumped on filling out our next topic, we're gonna try giving a this new quiet time format a shot. Over the next week we're gonna look at 6 prayer topics. If this isn't a good format, we can jump ship at anytime. If you feel like there is too little content for the day, huzzah! You could pray over that topic.

For today, feel free to dig into some of your favorite prayers in the bible and/or try and learn something new about prayer. You could even pray about it!

The verses for each section will be in the comments and here are the topics

- Prayer Overview
- What is Prayer
- Prayers of Thanksgiving and Gratitude
- Prayer in Repentance
- Praying for others
- Listening in Prayer
- Daily Prayer

Free game to use this time how you wish.

Kenny: Any ideas for our next study topic or book or chapters? I threw in Habakkuk for funsies

Zechariah 8:22, Luke 11:1-4, Luke 11:9-10, Psalm 23, Matthew 21:22

Devon: I do not think that prayer is our method of making appeals to God. I believe that prayer is simply our way of having conversation with the Lord just as we would with any other person; it's how we talk to him, how we pour out our hearts to him. With that in mind, as we talk with him and converse, we also make requests and appeals and this is certainly not a bad thing (Philippians 4:6). So then I suppose it's more the mindset of how we approach prayer rather than what we say during that prayer.

John 11:41, Psalm 100

The High Priestly Prayer in John 17 is a really good example of that.

He loved us before we loved him, and heard our prayers, and listens to us. That alone is mind boggling, and worthy of every ounce of thankfulness my will can muster.

Devon: Looks like my comment didn't get saved. That's a downer. Basically the idea is that I want to look at biblical characters who walked with the Lord over a long period of time and I want to examine from the start of their life to the end of their life the effects of the process of sanctification. How did their opinion of themselves change between the beginning and the end? How did their opinion of God change from the beginning to the end? How did their method of interacting and viewing the world change from the beginning to the end, etc. I personally want to do Paul but I'd love to see David, Moses, Abraham, Samuel, Peter, etc. Hopefully this saves.

Kenny: I did my own thing for the last 2 days. Sorry for the late start, but today I am jumping into this character study. The character that I am going to dig into is Isaiah.

Corey: I'm also getting a late start. I'm gonna start by looking into Elijah, seeing how much I can dig into on him.

Devon: It was hard to see large effects of sanctification over the course of Paul's life. In general he uses the same bold policy of rebuke and correction throughout his ministry, he uses much of the same figures of speech and teaching patterns, and he generally considers his own life worth very little. However, one thing that I thought was super super cool about Paul was how he refers to himself over the course of his life. It is believed that Galatians may have been Paul's very first letter (A.D. 49 early guess) and if not his first it was an early letter (A.D. 53 late guess). In this letter he refers to himself as "an apostle to the Gentiles" as Peter was "an apostle to the Jews". Later when he wrote 1 Corinthians (A.D. 54/55), he refers to himself as "the least of the apostles". After this when he wrote Ephesians (A.D. 60) he refers to himself as "the least of all God's people". And finally, at the end of his life when he wrote 1 Timothy (likely his second last book in A.D. 63/65) he counts himself among sinners "of whom I am the worst". That was pretty cool to look into and see over the course of his life.

Corey: Verses 25-40 discussing marriage just baffle me! They feel out of place with how the rest of scripture treats marriage. I would clearly say from the rest of scripture that marriage is Gods design - citing Genesis, Song of Soloman, and Ephesians - that marriage is Gods design. Yet, in this passage, Paul claims it is best for the unmarried to remain such. As if staying unmarried is superior to Gods design of marriage. What do you guys make of this passage? (Obviously, this passage feels extra sharp as a man who is actively preparing to transition from unmarried to married)

Devon RE Corey: I mentioned to you today that I'm sure there is a bit more to this than we get to see (verse 7:1) so it's hard to say what their question to him actually was and why he is making this point. With that said, Paul explains the "why" of what he means very clearly here which makes me happy because so often things seem obscure and it's hard to tell what's actually being said (now we just need to figure out the context of the "why"). In verses 32-38 he states what he means and objectively this is true that marriage will present constraints on the Christian life that may prohibit a complete following of Christ to the ends of the earth (if that's your calling). But just like Paul says, getting married is obviously not a sin and no one would argue that it's not God's design (certainly not Paul). I think there are clearly certain advantages to marriage in our life of witness; a good example of this is Ivan and his wife throwing house parties for their block, this would be much harder to do effectively as a single person. Or take raising children, which is clearly beneficial and glorifying to the Lord. So then there is benefit to both and God is pleased with both. Certainly Paul is not arguing that marriage is a second rate institution to singleness. After reading several articles on the subject there are a number of ways you can look at this and it's hard to say which is "exactly correct" but I will say that it makes sense if you consider the actual gift of celibacy; In that light Paul is saying that if you do have the gift of celibacy (not exactly common) then you should try to avoid marriage because He has better plans for you in that singleness. I really like Focus on the Family and they have a pretty good article on it here: https://www.focusonthefamily.com/family-q-and-a/relationships-and-marriage/the-apostle-paul-on-marriage-and-singleness

Josh: A while ago, a pastor of mine gave a sermon on money. Close to the end of his sermon, and he was sharing some practical application for whatever money-passage we were going through, he made a bold statement on how we as Christians should give. He boldly included "Give to your local church first." He also said that there is scriptural evidence to say that that should be the case. Could this passage be what he is talking about? I absolutely believe that we should give to our local church. You can find sources for that all over the place. But FIRST? What the heck. He's absolutely a Biblical pastor, and he's incredibly wise, so that really threw me. I'm wondering if I should be convicted because Kayleigh and I don't make our giving decisions with our church as our number 1 first thought.
Devon RE Josh: That's a really interesting question. I don't think I could make a sound biblical argument for either side without a good deal more study. My gut reaction based on a simple knowledge of God and Scripture would be to say that we should give first where it is most effective or most needed. Or perhaps you might say where it will do the most good. My old church (DFC) was a fairly wealthy church and it certainly did a lot of great stuff but I remember one Easter when they put on this huge easter egg event for kids and it was cool but they bought these premade easter baskets for every single kid that attended (probably several hundred) and each basket must have been $10 to $20 bucks. And I remember being convicted about it because I thought to myself "surely this is not the most effective way that this church can be spending $20,000". That memory has stuck with me for a long time and whenever I think about giving I always think "Is this really going to be put to the most effective use for the Kingdom?". Now maybe those baskets changed some kid's lives and really was super effective; I know God can work with anything in any way he wants, small or big. So I'm really not sure when it comes right down to it; I just remember that event and I think about it a lot.
Kenny: this is slightly off topic from the original question, but I wanted to say that one thing that I really appreciate about my church is that when they preach on money, they will take the offering before the service. I've also asked Drew Frazer about this before, since he fundraises his salar, if he ever feels convicted on buying expensive things. He would say that his decision to buy something is between him and the Lord. Yeah, he may buy something totally seemingly unrelated to the gospel, but that's not for me to say what he should and shouldn't buy. I'm sure there are 100s of silly things that I've bought over the years that wasn't exactly kingdom minded. As for a church spending $20k on Easter egg baskets, I agree that it seems completely ridiculous, but if one person who was slightly more encouraged towards God's kingdom because if those baskets, then yeah I'd say it was worth it. People do appreciate excellence.

Devon: I love verse 1 where it says that knowledge puffs up but love builds up. This is convicting to me to a degree because I often pray for greater knowledge and a better memory but as I consider my reasons for this, a part of it is simply because of pride. As I look throughout history or even at what I see today, it is a very rare thing to change someone's mind by proving them wrong; on the contrary, people are continuously changed because of the conviction brought on them by the love of someone who wasn't trying to win an argument but rather to simply love them. Truly love wins far more hearts than the best "argument" ever will.
Josh: well said, bro. I've been thinking about this in myself as well lately.
Kenny: I've been finding myself getting in arguments at work lately to do things one way or another. Usually it gets to the point where I am arguing my pride instead of arguing towards a better way to do something. This was a good reminder for me to hear. Thanks Devon!
Kenny: I love that illustration in verses 24-27

Devon: Ugh... Something I struggle with trying to understand biblically is when we see passages like this that we clearly don't follow. I've talked to a lot of people who would say "Well, it doesn't apply because Paul was addressing a specific issue to a specific people group" or "Whoever was talking about something that only applied for that particular point in time because it was cultural." etc. That is such a dangerous way of looking at the bible because nearly everything in the Word was written for a specific purpose, to a specific people, at a specific point in time. This is what allows us to twist the word into false doctrines and terrible practices.

Kenny RE Devon: This is a tricky one because I stand behind verses that say things like: men shouldn't have long hair, etc. However, in verses 5 and 6 it talks about how a wife should wear a head covering when she is praying. My commentary on those verses say "A married woman who uncovered her head in public would have brought shame to her husband. The action may have connoted sexual availability or may simply have been a sign of being unmarried. In cultures where womens head coverings are not a sign of being married, wives do not need to cover their heads in worship, but they could obey this command by wearing some other physical symbol of being married (such as a wedding ring). While a shaven head or short hair was considered shameful for a woman in first-century Corinth, long hair was considered to be a womans glory". For me, this commentary is relatable because I think it would be ridiculous for Aubrey to wear a head covering when she prays and it's completely understandable for her to wear her wedding ring all of the time.

Kenny: I wonder how many Epistles end with Paul wanting to see them and also intends to send Timothy to them too.

Devon RE Kenny: Haha he had a ton of people who he ministered to so I'm not surprised that he simply could not make time for all of them.

Kenny: I had a few takeaways from going through this book. One of them is the idea that some of these "quotable" verses that we use all of the time are in the context of passages that I would not expect them to be in. For example 10:13 (the no temptation verse has overtaken you verse), 9:24-27 (the don't you know that in a race all of the runners run) and a few others are in the context of "Food Offered to Idols". I would have expected verses like that to be in a context of something like: "how to be a better Christian". I don't think that the context of these verses takes away anything from them, but I think it's a good reminder that verses in the bible do have a context which needs to be considered before making bold claims on them.

Also, what do you guys want to read next?

Devon RE Kenny: Yea that's a good thought, Kenny. I'm not sure what my major takeaway is really. I think there were some good reminders in there but I like the thoughts you had. As for next book, I suppose 2 Cor?

Kenny RE Devon: 2 Cor sounds good to me. Most of the chapters are ~20 verses. Feel free to divvy it up differently as you see fit.

Kenny: Some highlights from my study bible are, 2 Cor is the most personal of all of Paul's letters, filled with deep emotion. Also, 2 Cor was written a year after 1 Cor and a year before Romans.

Devon RE Kenny: Oh I hope so!!! We never got a straight answer lol!

Kenny: V4: "For I wrote to you out of much affliction and anguish of heart and with many tears, not to cause you pain but to let you know the abundant love that I have for you." What a genuine care for others Paul demonstrates here.

Devon: That's a very interesting chapter. I'm not sure I really know what Paul is really getting at. Certainly he wants to boast of what God has done in his life and he also wants to highlight what he has gone through in his witness to Christ but I"m not sure why he approaches it as he does.

Kenny RE Devon: It seems uncharacteristic of Paul to have to boast like this considering the fact that he said in verse 8: "I robbed other churches by accepting support...". My only thought is that he has to boast like that to deal with the false prophets and what they're teaching to the Corinthians.

Corey: I'd vote for either more Psalms next, or a minor prophet. Perhaps the short minor prophets, like Obadiah, Nahum,  and Haggai? Maybe some study to connect each of those OT prophets to the fulfilled prophecies?

Kenny RE Corey: I'd be up for any of those ideas.
Kenny: I'm just picking random Psalms that I like until we establish something

Corey: Now that the Proposal is done and my head is back on my shoulders - I'm back boys!!!! And I've got a series that intrigues me at least. I'm not sure what we'll find - but the best way to find out is to dig in! I want to spend some time in the minor prophets. I feel least knowledgeable about those little books. So here's what I'm aiming to do in each chapter of each book that is 3 chapters or less:
1. Identify fulfilled prophecies in the text
2. Identify how the text is references by New Testament authors
3. Identify yet to be fulfilled prophecies 
The objective I'm trying to reach here is to gain understanding of the purpose of these books, especially in tandem with the New Testament, and gain some respect for the way God operates through prophets. I realize that a good chunk of these passages may be "Israel is doomed!!!!!!" style prophecies - but alas, that is no reason to avoid studying them. What can we pull from these "fly-over" books of the Bible?

Kenny RE Corey: Thanks for putting this together Corey! I'm excited to dig into this

Corey: I discovered that Obadiah is one of relatively few OT books with no direct quotations in the NT. In general, I had a tough time drawing Obadiah to the NT much at all, beyond some cross references to Revelation regarding "The Day of the Lord."

Devon: I really liked in verse 4 where it says "he rebukes the sea". This reminds me of Jesus when he rebuked the sea to calm in and when you realize that this is a prophecy about God himself and his mighty power, it is no wonder the disciples were terrified and worshiped him when he did it.

Kenny: RE Q's 1, 2 and 3.
Question #1: 1:9-15 talk about the judgement of Nineveh. We see this prophecy fulfilled in Jonah.
Question #2: 1:15 and Romans 10:15 are similar because they both talk about the feet of those who bring good news.
Question #3: I don't see any examples of unfulfilled prophesies here.

Corey: Nice parallel Devon! I didn't pick up on that immediately - but that's an impressive parallel. I like how it connects God the Father and Christ the Son as aspects of the trinity. Kenny - I'm not so sure we see the fulfillment in Jonah. Jonah closes with a repentant Nineveh, and my commentary notes that Jonah went to Nineveh 100 years before Nahum's prophecy. Now, I know that isn't the standard of truth - and the prophecy has been fulfilled by the fact that Nineveh isn't exactly on the map anymore - but I don't know that we see the destruction of Nineveh in the scripture directly.

Josh: Yeah I'm pretty sure Nahum is pretty long after the conversion at Ninevah. That's why it makes sense that God is mad enough to wipe them out in that case, because they had been a nation to follow Him, and now (during Nahum) they were not

Kenny: Yep, you guys are right. Thanks for catching this! For some reason I thought Jonah ended with a judgement and not repentance.
Kenny: verse 4 is a popular one in the NT! Romans 1:17, Galatians 3:11 and Hebrews 10:38

Devon: What are your guys' thoughts on verse 13 where it says that God cannot be tempted by evil? We are told that Jesus was tempted by evil in the desert.

Kenny RE Devon: We are also told in Hebrews 4:13 that Jesus was tempted in every way that we are, yet without sin. I wonder if this is just one of those things that I'll never fully understand the depths to Jesus being fully man and fully God at the same time.

Devon RE Kenny: Yea you might be right. I think one thing that makes a lot of sense to me is the idea that God is pure Spirit and that Spirit cannot be temptable. But Christ is unique in that he is fully man and fully God. Therefore it was not the spiritual part of Christ that was tempted but rather the flesh that was tempted which is why he was able to experience everything that we suffer and have to face.

Devon - James 1:27. My parents were a part of an organization called Project 1:27 that was founded based on this verse. In fact it is this verse that lead them to become a foster home and to adopt 5 kids into our house. My question for you guys, then, is what does this verse look like practically for us today? I personally don't think that everyone is called to adopt children but how to we carry out this verse practically in our daily or yearly lives?
Josh: It is more acceptable to do these sorts of things as a group, rather than going by yourself to an orphanage or something. We as a Church should be caring for orphans and widows together. Therefore, I think that we can carry out this verse practically by getting involved in our local churches for these specific things. Serve/play at an orphanage with the kiddos. Serve/love widows in your church, or see if there's some sort of outreach for widows in your community. All in all, these topics are talked about in the context of true religion, which assumes you have a group.

Josh: Verse 2:13 confuses me. If I wasn't a believer and I lived a whole life showing mercy, am I exempt from God's judgement? I know the answer is no, but how does that fit into this text?

Devon RE Josh: I think this opens a can of worms to a much broader topic regarding levels of accountability at judgement and that's a whole nother beast. With that said, I simply take this verse to mean that lack of mercy is a severe offense and whether in this life or the next, judgement will be given based on that. The verse before this seems to be talking about worldly forms of judgement or heavenly forms of rewards (my notes say that and I can get behind it since it talks about judgement for Christians which we know are saved through the blood of Christ). So I would probably take this verse in that context also but I'm really not sure all around.

Devon: I was thinking about why James associates Envy and Selfish Ambition with "every evil practice" instead of a host of other things that I would have guesses also lead to all kinds of evil. But as I thought about it I realized that envy causes us to want all that other people have and to covet it and ruin our own happiness because we can't stop thinking about it. Now couple that with selfish ambition which drives us to get what we want at any and all cost. Put these two together and you have a dangerous combination that will do anything and stop at nothing to achieve all that they do not have. James was a smart dude.
Devon: I have never understood how verse 17 plays into his current discourse. It's a great verse, sure, but what does it have to do with what he just got done talking about?
